intro: Napus, commonly known as turnip or rape, is a member of the Brassicaceae family. It is a biennial or annual plant that typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm. The plant features thick, fleshy leaves and a swollen, edible root that can vary in color from white to purple. Its flowers are small and yellow, arranged in racemes, and it produces long, slender pods containing rounded seeds. Napus is cultivated for its edible parts, including the leaves, roots, and seeds, and is also used in agriculture for oil production.
